content: The Act may be cited as the "VA Expiring Authorities Extension Act of 2013" and includes a table of contents. The "VA Expiring Authorities Extension Act of 2013" includes provisions for extending various programs and authorities related to disabled veterans, adaptive sports assistance, transportation to VA facilities, nursing home care, mental health services, housing assistance for homeless veterans, and advisory committees. The "VA Expiring Authorities Extension Act of 2013" extends authority for the Veterans' Advisory Commission on Education, requirements for vendee loans, and medical disabilities examinations. It also references Title 38, United States Code, and addresses budgetary effects. Additionally, it extends authorization of appropriations for monthly assistance allowance to disabled veterans training or competing. The monthly assistance allowance for disabled veterans training or competing in large-scale adaptive sports programs is reauthorized through 2015. The cooperation with the United States Olympic Committee is amended to include entities experienced in managing such programs. The provisions now apply to Commonwealths and Territories of the United States, including American Samoa and Guam. SEC. 5. REAUTHORIZATION AND MODIFICATION OF ADAPTIVE SPORTS ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. The Secretary may make grants to eligible entities for adaptive sports programs for disabled veterans and Armed Forces members. Eligible entities must have experience in managing large-scale adaptive sports programs. The Secretary may make grants to eligible entities for adaptive sports programs for disabled veterans and Armed Forces members. Eligible entities must provide details on partnerships, grant funds allocation, financial controls, performance metrics, and use of funds for administrative expenses. Eligible entities receiving grants for adaptive sports programs can use a portion of the grant for administrative and personnel expenses. The amount for such expenses is limited to 10% for fiscal year 2014, 7.5% for fiscal year 2015, and 5% for subsequent years. Personnel expenses cover costs related to employees not directly involved in coaching or training disabled veterans or Armed Forces members. Funding for these grants is specified in subsection (g) of the section. The section is amended to extend funding through 2015 and limit assistance for adaptive sports opportunities to fiscal years 2010 through 2016. A report on grant usage must be submitted to Congress within 18 months of enactment. It requires a report on grant usage to be submitted to Congress within 18 months of enactment. Grantees have provided adaptive sports opportunities to veterans and members of the Armed Forces through grants awarded under the section. The Secretary oversees fund usage, and programs benefit veterans and members of the Armed Forces. Technical and conforming amendments are made to Section 521A. The section amends funding through 2015 and limits assistance for adaptive sports to fiscal years 2010-2016. It requires a report on grant usage to be sent to Congress within 18 months. Grantees offer adaptive sports to veterans and Armed Forces members. The Secretary oversees fund usage, and programs benefit these individuals. Technical amendments are made to Section 521A. The section amends funding for adaptive sports programs, changing references to the United States Olympic Committee to an eligible entity. It also updates terminology to refer to adapted sports opportunities funded by grants. The section updates funding for adaptive sports programs by changing references to the United States Olympic Committee to eligible entities and updating terminology for adapted sports opportunities funded by grants. It also includes provisions regarding reporting requirements for grant recipients and clerical amendments to section headings and table of sections. The section updates funding for adaptive sports programs for disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may implement regulations through interim final rules to ensure grants for adaptive sports are awarded before the end of fiscal year 2014. Additionally, authorities for transporting individuals to VA facilities, operating the VA regional office in Manila, and providing nursing home care to certain veterans with service-connected disabilities are extended until December 31, 2014. The extension of various services for homeless veterans, including treatment, rehabilitation, housing assistance, and advisory committees, has been prolonged until December 31, 2014. Additionally, requirements regarding vendee loans have been extended until September 30, 2014. SEC. 14. Extension of authority for medical disabilities examinations by contract physicians until December 31, 2014.
